Award.AwardTitle: CPS:Medium:Quantitative Visual Sensing of Dynamic Behaviors for Home-based Progressive Rehabilitation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop a comprehensive theoretical and experimental cyber-physical framework to enable intelligent human-environment interaction capabilities by a synergistic combination of computer vision and robotics. Specifically, the approach is applied to examine individualized remote rehabilitation with an intelligent, articulated, and adjustable lower limb orthotic brace to manage Knee Osteoarthritis, where a visual-sensing/dynamical-systems perspective is adopted to: (1) track and record patient/device interactions with internet-enabled commercial-off-the-shelf computer-vision-devices; (2) abstract the interactions into parametric and composable low-dimensional manifold representations; (3) link to quantitative biomechanical assessment of the individual patients; (4) facilitate development of individualized user models and exercise regimen; and (5) aid the progressive parametric refinement of exercises and adjustment of bracing devices. This research and its results will enable us to understand underlying human neuro-musculo-skeletal and locomotion principles by merging notions of quantitative data acquisition, and lower-order modeling coupled with individualized feedback. Beyond efficient representation, the quantitative visual models offer the potential to capture fundamental underlying physical, physiological, and behavioral mechanisms grounded on biomechanical assessments, and thereby afford insights into the generative hypotheses of human actions.

Knee osteoarthritis is an important public health issue, because of high costs associated with treatments. The ability to leverage a quantitative paradigm, both in terms of diagnosis and prescription, to improve mobility and reduce pain in patients would be a significant benefit. Moreover, the home-based rehabilitation setting offers not only immense flexibility, but also access to a significantly greater portion of the patient population. The project is also integrated with extensive educational and outreach activities to serve a variety of communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
By completing this project, a comprehensive cyber-physical system framework has been created and thoroughly investigated for quantitatively sensing, analyzing, decomposing, understanding, and modulating human behaviors through wearable robotic systems and low-cost computer vision devices in the application of home-based progressive rehabilitation. The latest version of such cyber-physical system could track and record, under carefully controlled conditions, low-level dynamic behaviors and patient/device interaction in the scenarios with support through the Kinect visual sensing system; may link to quantitative biomechanical assessment of the individual patients to aid the development of individualized user model and exercise regimen; and virtually assist in the progressive parametric refinement of exercises and adjustment of OA bracing device. From a broader societal perspective, knee osteoarthritis is an important public health issue, because of high costs associated with treatments. The ability to leverage a quantitative paradigm, both in terms of diagnosis and prescription, to improve mobility and reduce pain in patients would be a significant benefit. Moreover, the home-based rehabilitation setting offers not only immense flexibility, but also access to a significantly greater portion of the patient population.

The key project outcomes include 1) a newly collected and quantitatively annotated synchronized multi-modal dataset with adding various sensors (Kinect/Vicon/IMU data: accelerometers, gyroscopes, encoders, flexiforce tactile and force-torque sensors) for over 20 independent subjects (still increasing), each performing more than 6 different actions from the same set of actions (squatting, hurdling, knee lift) to form the basis for a longitudinal study; 2) prototyping and evaluating the design of low-cost, articulated semi-passive wearable smart knee brace systems with numerous adjustable parameters to modulate the bidirectional kinesthetic (motion and force) interactions in for assisting knee OA patients; 3) novel computational methodologies  of domain adaptation and data fusion based on the large scale manifold learning and robust sub-manifolds decomposition and matching, to fundamentally understand underlying human neuro-musculo-skeletal and locomotion principles by merging notions of quantitative data acquisition, and lower-order modeling coupled with individualized feedback. Such new techniques have been integrated with sparse graph, tensor representation, deep learning, graph embedding, subspace learning, multi-view learning, multisource, and transfer learning for model generalization; 4) low-cost and quantitative cyber visual components for action recognition and prediction through multiple sensors, such as Max-Margin Heterogeneous Information Machine, Discriminative Relational Representation Learning, and Max-Margin Prediction Machine, etc.  The visual models offer the potential to capture fundamental underlying physical, physiological, and behavioral mechanisms grounded on biomechanical assessments, and thereby afford insights into the generative hypotheses of human actions. The full computational evaluations have been conducted on action/activity recognition, re-identification, classification, inference and prediction scenarios; and 5) more than 145 peer-reviewed publications in conference proceedings, journals, and books.

Throughout the whole project duration, the research has been integrated with extensive educational and outreach activities to serve a variety of communities, including the NSF Young Scholars/RET/REU programs and Gordon Scholar program at Northeastern University. In total, more than 15 local high school and undergraduate students have been involved in this project. The students have engaged in the data collection and acquisition, annotation, development of code that was used for cyber-physical system interfaces and modules. Technical background information and hands-on supervisions were provided. Self-motivation, initiative taking, and ability to work independently and collaboratively were fully encouraged. Research has been conducted cross multiple projects with successful team-work.
